    Understanding Protocols

    What is Protocol:

    A protocol is a standard set of rules that allow devices to communicate with each other. It includes what type of data may be transmitted, what commands are used to send and receive data, and how data transfers are confirmed. Here we are using four types of protocol. They are Modbus RTU, Modbus TCP/IP, Modbus Telnet, and MQTT. The Protocol list will be explained below.

    Modbus RTU:

    Modbus RTU is an open serial protocol derived from the Master/Slave architecture. It is a simple 16-bit structure with a CRC (Cyclic-Redundant Checksum). The simplicity of these messages is to ensure reliability. This protocol primarily uses an RS-232 or RS-485 serial interfaces for communications.

    The Modbus RTU protocol uses a Master/Slave technique to communicate between devices i.e., any application that utilizes the Modbus RTU protocol will have a Modbus Master and at least one Modbus Slave.

    Modbus TCP/IP:

    This is a Modbus variant used for communications over TCP/IP networks, connecting over port 502. It does not require a checksum calculation, as lower layers already provide checksum protection.

    Modbus Telnet:

    Telnet is a protocol used on the Internet or local area network to provide a bidirectional interactive text-oriented communication facility using a virtual terminal connection. User data is interspersed in-band with Telnet control information in an 8-bit byte oriented data connection over the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP).

    MQTT:

    MQTT stands for Message Queuing Telemetry Transport and it is designed as a lightweight messaging protocol that uses publish/subscribe operations to exchange data between clients and the server. MQTT is based on clients and a server, the server is responsible for handling the clients requests of receiving or sending data between each other. MQTT server is called a broker and the clients are simply the connected devices. So: When a device (a client) wants to send data to the broker, we call this operation a publish. When a device (a client) wants to receive data from the broker, we call this operation a subscribe. MQTT Components: Broker, which is the server that handles the data transmission between the clients. A topic, which is the place a device, wants to put or retrieve a message to/from. The message, which is the data that a device receives when subscribing from a topic or send when publishing to a topic. Publish, is the process a device does to send its message to the broker. Subscribe, where a device does to retrieve a message from the broker.
